TopicTitle: Paper Space Program 1.8 (KSP Rocket Parts papercraft)

Articles.Content:
Awesome! Now the only thing I need is a new printer cartridge Should get around to it in a few days.

EDIT: Actually realised that I have a spare one XD AND THIS THING IS HUUUUUGEEEEE!

http://i.imgur.com/pEwDwAc.jpg

Apparently the new wings are a lot larger than the old ones. I always assumed that the old delta wing was the same size as the new one but apparently the new one is like huge or smth:

http://i.imgur.com/WaRiHr0.jpg

(I actually went to check the sizes in game and apprently squad did enlarge the wings O.o)

I'm pretty sure I got the general scale right:

http://i.imgur.com/RGnNfDy.jpg

Oh my god , looks like there's a real lot things to do

BTW , looking at yesterday's KSPtv 1.0 stream i have a real lot of things to unfold

Oh my god , looks like there's a real lot things to do

BTW , looking at yesterday's KSPtv 1.0 stream i have a real lot of things to unfold

Yeah I'm looking foreward to the new nose cones and wings

Got the main body done:

The Mk3 cockpit is simply amazing, great work on unfolding it! I did a little mod on the front windows, so they have a bit of en indent, makes them look just so much better.

The tank top/bottom textures are a bit low-res though, I wonder how that happened.

And the bay does kinda close but it doesn't exactly fit, because i'm a faliure of a human being

I guess I'm just gonna have to display it opened

Yeah I'm looking foreward to the new nose cones and wings

Got the main body done:

http://i.imgur.com/WFZjtd1.jpg

The Mk3 cockpit is simply amazing, great work on unfolding it! I did a little mod on the front windows, so they have a bit of en indent, makes them look just so much better.

http://i.imgur.com/sKXIjp6.jpg

The tank top/bottom textures are a bit low-res though, I wonder how that happened.

http://i.imgur.com/lrhgJUj.jpg

And the bay does kinda close but it doesn't exactly fit, because i'm a faliure of a human being

http://i.imgur.com/sGhfHEy.jpg

I guess I'm just gonna have to display it opened

Despite the low resolution at the back , i'm very happy how the parts turned out to look really good Great work !

Edited April 26, 2015 by arc5555

It's looking great, MoffKalast!

I'm curious: what paper/cardboard are you using? I've been using 120 g/m^2 bond paper (80 lb Text I think it's called).

It's looking great, MoffKalast!

I'm curious: what paper/cardboard are you using? I've been using 120 g/m^2 bond paper (80 lb Text I think it's called).

Me too

It's looking great, MoffKalast!

I'm curious: what paper/cardboard are you using? I've been using 120 g/m^2 bond paper (80 lb Text I think it's called).

Me too

Thanks, I'm using 200g/m^2 paper, which is great for larger builds like this although the stuff doesn't always want to bend the way I want. I'ts pretty strong so in theory I could throw most of my models (at least the ones with no tiny parts) across the room and they'd be fine

For the glue i'm using UHU universal twist & glue, same as Arc I think.

Thanks, I'm using 200g/m^2 paper, which is great for larger builds like this although the stuff doesn't always want to bend the way I want. I'ts pretty strong so in theory I could throw most of my models (at least the ones with no tiny parts) across the room and they'd be fine

For the glue i'm using UHU universal twist & glue, same as Arc I think.

Yes, from your Mk3 pictures I was under the impression that was a much heavier paper. Very nice. A normal printer is still good with that? Do you cut it with an x-acto knife? Any tricks for bending/rolling such heavy paper? Remember I'm still learning here, so tricks are very welcome.

Also, I've been using toothpicks and an UHU-like transparent glue, but that applicator looks handy.

Yes, from your Mk3 pictures I was under the impression that was a much heavier paper. Very nice. A normal printer is still good with that? Do you cut it with an x-acto knife? Any tricks for bending/rolling such heavy paper? Remember I'm still learning here, so tricks are very welcome.

Also, I've been using toothpicks and an UHU-like transparent glue, but that applicator looks handy.

Yep, even my old printer (HP deskjet 840C) can handle it with ease. I cut it with scissors mostly and the fine parts with an x-acto. Well the process I use for rolling it is gently wrapping it around a smaller and smaller cylinder (like a pen or some other cylindrical thing that happens to be in my vincinity at the time ) untill I get it bent enough. For normal bending I use a ruler.

Btw arc, did you ever try to build the LV-909? I think it's not quite right or something may be missing from the pattern. Like the entire nozzle.
Isn't this the nozzle? The LV-909 has a short nozzle.

Isn't this the nozzle? The LV-909 has a short nozzle.

http://i.imgur.com/ELswxNW.png

Yes , it is You'd need some support to hold it in place though
I've been adding additional support to some parts using small paper strips cut from the leftovers. Works really well. Don't know if this is what people do.

I've been adding additional support to some parts using small paper strips cut from the leftovers. Works really well. Don't know if this is what people do.

I do the same thing

Well , it wasn't that great so i cut it out from the picture

Fantastic job, MoffKalast! The final result is really impressive.

So what did you do for the LV-909s? Added a base of some sort?

Thanks, i'm quite satisfied with it too For the LV-909 I had to improvise a bit, so I cut out some of the FL-T400 top covers and made an inside platform to which i could attach the nozzle (and a support so it held up). I also used the same parts for the nozzle inner parts (you can notice some bolts on the edges if you look closely), as I already had them printed but didnt end up using them anyway.

Well, it wasn't that great so i cut it out from the picture
